You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bcb}{twelve} Selic Rate, Monetary Policy, Inflation, Aggregate Demand, Food Prices, Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. Increasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation drops below lower limit of tolerance band. Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the moderation in the pace of growth was noticeable in all components of domestic demand, and resulted, in part, from the policy actions implemented since the end of 2010, intensified by the deterioration of the global economic scenario since the third quarter of last year\n                "}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence implies that the moderation in growth was partly due to policy actions, suggesting that the current monetary policy is sufficient to stimulate economic activity, and no further contractionary measures are needed."
}

\\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. Increasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation drops below lower limit of tolerance band. Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee understands that the effects of the complexity surrounding the international environment added up to those stemming from the moderation of domestic activity\n                "}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports on the committee's understanding of the current economic situation without suggesting any particular policy action or stance."

Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in the industrial countries, as a response to the incidents of september 11th in the united states, a slowdown in the consumption is observed, notwithstanding the drastic cut in interest rates made by the major central banks\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bcb}{twelve} Selic Rate, Monetary Policy, Inflation, Aggregate Demand, Food Prices, Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee analyzed an alternative scenario with stable interest rates over the entire relevant horizon\n                "}]

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bcb}{twelve} Selic Rate, Monetary Policy, Inflation, Aggregate Demand, Food Prices, Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. Increasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation drops below lower limit of tolerance band. Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. Increasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation drops below lower limit of tolerance band. Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: these estimates naturally and subsequent years\n                "}]

It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. Increasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation drops below lower limit of tolerance band. Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee members also measures of exchange-rate pass-through to both mentioned the growing risks to the continued inflation and underlying inflation\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: notwithstanding expectations of lesser primary surpluses in the final months of the year, 1999 fiscal performance has been quite satisfactory and easily surpassed the targets defined in the economic program agreed upon with the imf\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bcb}{twelve} Selic Rate, Monetary Policy, Inflation, Aggregate Demand, Food Prices, Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. 2025-05-03 21:08:58,106 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Central Bank of Brazil\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bcb}{twelve} Selic Rate, Monetary Policy, Inflation, Aggregate Demand, Food Prices, Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. Increasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation drops below lower limit of tolerance band. Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the current conditions of world growth have negatively impacted brazilian exports as to what demand and prices are concerned\n                "}]

"justification": "The sentence implies that the economy is facing external headwinds, which could lead to weaker aggregate demand and prices, suggesting a need for expansionary monetary policy."

unanimously decided to increase the Selic rate by 0.50 p.p. to 11.25\\% p.a.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} Increasing the interest rate is a contractionary move aimed at curbing inflation, indicating that policymakers are concerned about an overheating economy or rising inflation pressures. \n    \n    \\item “Copom assessed that the scenario—marked by resilient economic activity, labor market pressures, a positive output gap, increased inflation projections, and deanchored expectations—requires a more contractionary monetary policy.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Hawkish:} The sentences describes a condition (a positive output gap and rising inflation expectations) that justify tightening monetary policy to prevent the economy from overheating. \n    \n    \\item “All members agreed that it was appropriate to reduce the Selic rate by 0.50 percentage points.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} A reduction in the interest rate is an expansionary action designed to stimulate economic activity. It reflects a concern that the economy might be underperforming, requiring expansionary monetary policy. \n    \n    \\item “The combination of a robust labor market, expansionary fiscal policy, and vigorous lending to households continues to support consumption and, consequently, aggregate demand.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Dovish:} The sentence implies that the economy is receiving supportive stimulus from other sectors, reducing the immediate need for tighter monetary policy. Even though it recognizes strong economic activity, it suggests that current measures are sufficient without extra contractionary steps. \n    \n    \\item “The labor market, which surprised positively throughout 2022, has shown resilience, with a net increase in job creation and relative stability in the unemployment rate.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Neutral:} The sentence reports economic conditions—namely, stability in the labor market—without suggesting any particular policy action. It serves as an observation of the current economic state rather than a signal for change. \n\n    \\item “However, most of the committee members judged that this interpretation still seems premature and needs further corroboration by data.”\n    \\\\ \\textbf{Irrelevant:} This statement mainly expresses skepticism toward an interpretation and does not signal any explicit monetary policy direction or stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Central Bank of Brazil}} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\\textbf{Selic Rate} & Increase in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Decrease in Selic rate to combat inflation. & Selic rate remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Monetary Policy} & Central bank institutes contractionary or tightening monetary policy. & Central bank institutes expansionary or loosens monetary policy. & Monetary policy remains unchanged. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Inflation} & Inflation exceeds upper limit of the tolerance band. Increasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation drops below lower limit of tolerance band. Decreasing inflation, inflationary pressures or expectations of inflation. & Inflation is within the central bank’s target range, with inflation and expectations stable. COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: it shall be stressed that the yen has shown appreciating trend vis-a-vis the american dollar inasmuch as the perspectives for longer deceleration in us become more evident\n                "}]

"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the exchange rate between the yen and the American dollar, which is not directly related to the Central Bank of Brazil's monetary policy."

Industrial Goods Prices, Services Prices, Labor Market, GDP Growth, Exchange Rate, Trade Deficit, and the Cattle Cycle.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Selic Rate}: The benchmark interest rate set by Brazil's central bank.\n    \\item \\emph{Monetary Policy}: The process by which the central bank controls the money supply, typically through adjustments to interest rates.\n    \\item \\emph{Inflation}: The rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, reflecting changes in purchasing power.\n    \\item \\emph{Aggregate Demand}: The total demand for goods and services in an economy at a given overall price level and period.\n    \\item \\emph{Food Prices}: The market prices of food products.\n    \\item \\emph{Industrial Goods Prices}: The prices of manufactured goods produced in industrial settings.\n    \\item \\emph{Services Prices}: The prices charged for common services.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: The interaction between workers and employers regarding employment, wages, and job availability.\n    \\item \\emph{GDP Growth}: The rate of increase in a country's Gross Domestic Product, indicating economic expansion.\n    \\item \\emph{Exchange rate (BRL)}: The value of the Brazilian Real in relation to foreign currencies.\n    \\item \\emph{Trade Deficit}: A situation where a country's imports exceed its exports.\n    \\item \\emph{Cattle Cycle}: The cyclical fluctuations in beef supply and prices driven by changes in cattle production.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples}\n\\begin{itemize} \n    \\item “Copom COPOM’s tolerance range for inflation is between 2\\% and 5\\%, with the target in the middle. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Aggregate Demand (AD)} & Increasing aggregate demand. & AD is insufficient or decreasing. & Balanced AD and Aggregate Supply (AS), stable inflation, and steady growth. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Food Prices} & Increasing or high food prices. & Decreasing or low food prices. & No change in food prices. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Industrial Goods Prices} & Increasing or high price of industrialized goods. & Decreasing or low price of industrialized goods. & No change in price of industrialized goods. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Services Prices} & Increasing or high service prices. & Decreasing or low service prices. & No change in price of services. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & Low or decreasing unemployment. Demand for workers exceeds available supply. Excessive wage growth. Creation of more jobs. & High or decreasing unemployment. Weak demand for labor; underemployment; stagnant wages. & Full employment without overheating, stable wage growth, and balanced labor supply and demand. Average unemployment is around 10\\%. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{GDP Growth} & GDP grows too quickly, accelerating beyond the country’s sustainable capacity. & Weak, negative (recession), or insufficient GDP growth to sustain full employment and price stability. & Stable GDP growth without excessive fluctuations. COPOM examines the circumstances and global context; on average, growth is around 1\\% quarterly. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Exchange rate (BRL)} & When the BRL depreciates. & When the BRL appreciates. & When a foreign currency appreciates or depreciates. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Trade Deficit} & Decrease in exports or increase in imports, leading to a higher trade deficit. & Increase in exports or decrease in imports, leading to a lower trade deficit. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Cattle Cycle} & Supply of beef is low, leading to higher prices. & Supply of beef is high, leading to lower prices. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\label{tb:bcb_mp_stance_guide}\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the main risks continue to relevant horizon for the conduct of monetary policy\n                "}]

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2.
